sections.title: Invariants in relativity theory
sections.abstract:
In the relativistic theory the principle of naturality of physical laws leads to differential equations admitting diffeomorphisms of space-time as symmetries.

In this paper we investigate differential invariants of actions of diffeomorphisms on (pseudo)-Riemann metrics, on solutions of the Einstein equation, and on solutions of the Einstein---Maxwell equation. We find the corresponding fields of rational differential invariants and the corresponding factor-equations.
sections.author: Valentin\,Lychagin \and Valeriy\,Yumaguzhin
sections.keywords: Einstein--Maxwell equation, differential invariant, jet bundle, factor equation
sections.introduction:
%
The general relativity theory is based on the naturality principle, or independence physical laws on coordinates. In other words this principle requires that physical laws should be invariant under an action of the  pseudogroup of local diffeomorphisms of space-time manifold. It is also implicitly assumed that physical fields are natural in the sense that the diffeomorphisms act also (in a natural way) on the fields. Thus the general theory of relativity deals with the metric tensor and the Einstein equations are invariant under diffeomorphisms. In the same way the relativistic theory of electromagnetism deals with pair of tensors: metric and Faraday and the Einstein--Maxwell equations are invariant under diffeomorphisms of space-time manifold.

Differential invariants, i.e. functions depending on fields and their derivatives and invariant under the diffeomorphism  pseudogroup might be considered as local observables in the theory. Thus for the gravity theory it is known (\cite{Hskns}, \cite{Wttn}) that there are fourteen independent differential invariants of order two (i.e. dependent on metric tensor and its derivatives up to order two).

In this paper we give a description of the fields of all rational differential invariants in the following three cases: (1) metrics, (2) Einstein metrics, i.e. solutions of the  vacuum Einstein equations, and (3) metrics together with Faraday tensors subjected to the Einstein--Maxwell equations.

Remark that in all three cases the  pseudogroup as well as PDE-systems satisfy the requirements of paper \cite{KrglkvLchgn} and to them might be applied the Lie-Tresse theorem. It is worth to mention that we restrict ourselves by rational differential invariants because they do separate regular orbits of diffeomorphism  pseudogroup in jet spaces.

The next but very important step consists of rewriting the PDE system in terms of invariants or observables. We do it for all three cases and get "universal system" of differential equations in all three cases.
\medskip
We would like to thank Alexei Kotov for valuable and helpful discussions.


%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
main_part:
%%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Notations}%
Let $M$ be an $n$-dimensional oriented manifold and let $\tau:TM\to M$ and $\tau^*:T^*M\to M$ be tangent and cotangent bundles. We will denote by $T_a$(or simply $T$) and  $T_a^*$(or $T^*$) a tangent and cotangent spaces at a point $a\in M$.

By $\Omega^k$ and $\Sigma^k$ we denote $C^{\infty}(M)$-modules of exterior differential $k$-forms, and symmetric differential $k$-forms respectively.

The  pseudogroup of all local diffeomorphisms of $M$ will be denoted by $\Dif$.

%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Jet bundles}%
Let $\pi:E(\pi)\to M$ be a vector bundle and $\Gamma(\pi)$ be the $C^{\infty}(M)$-module of its smooth sections. By $\pi_k:J^k\pi\to M$ we denote the bundles
of $k$-jets of sections of the bundle $\pi$ and by $\pi_{k,l}:J^k\pi\to J^l\pi$, $k\geq l$, natural projections defined by reductions of $k$-jet to $l$-jet.

Any section $s\in \Gamma(\pi)$ defines its $k$-prolongation $j_k(s)\in\Gamma(\pi_k)$, where 
$
  j_k(s)(a)=[s]_a^k
$,
and by $[s]_a^k$ we denote $k$-jet of section $s$ at the point $a\in M$.

%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Total derivatives}%
Let $X$ be a vector field on $M$. The total derivative along $X$ we denote by $\widehat X$. It is a derivation of functions given on jet bundles $\pi_k$$
   \widehat X: C^{\infty}(J^k\pi)\longrightarrow C^{\infty}(J^{k+1}\pi),
$$k=0,1,\ldots$, which satisfies the following conditions: 
$
  j_{k+1}(s)^*\circ\widehat X=X\circ j_k(s)^*
$
for all $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$.
 
Suppose $x^1$,$\ldots$,$x^n$ are local coordinates on $M$ and
$
   X=\sum_iX^i(x)\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i},
$$x^1$,$\ldots$,$x^n$,$u^1$,$\ldots$,$u^m$ are local coordinates in $\pi$, and $x^1$, $\ldots$, $x^n$, $u^1$, $\ldots$, $u^m$, $\ldots$, $u^j_{\sigma}$,$\ldots$ are canonical coordinates in $J^k(\pi)$ then
$
  \widehat X=\sum_iX^i(x)\frac{d}{d x^i},
$
where 
$$
  \frac{d}{d x^i}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}+u_i^j\frac{\partial}{\partial u^j}+
+\ldots+u_{ii_1\ldots i_k}^j\frac{\partial}{\partial u_{i_1\ldots i_k}^j}+\ldots
$$
are the total derivatives.

%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Total differentials}%
Let $f$ be a smooth function on the manifold $J^k\pi$. Then by its total differential $\widehat d f$ one means a horizontal differential 1-form on the manifold $J^{k+1}\pi$, which satisfies the following condition:
$
   j_{k+1}(s)^*(\widehat d f)=d\bigl(j_k(s)^*(f)\bigr).
$
In canonical coordinates the total differential has the form
$
\widehat d f=\sum_i\frac{df}{dx^i}dx^i.
$%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Differential groups}%
We denote by $\Dgr_k(a)$, $k=0,1,2,\ldots$, the set of $k$-jets at a point $a\in M$ of all diffeomorphisms of $M$ preserving this point, 
$
  \Dgr_k(a)=\{\;[\varphi]_a^k\;|\;\varphi\in\Dif\;\text{and}\;\varphi(a)=a\;\}.
$
The composition of diffeomorphisms preserving point $a$ induces the Lie group structure on $\Dgr_k(a)$ and the jet $e=[\id]_a^k$ is the neutral element of this group. 

It is clear that $\Dgr_1(a)$ is naturally identified with a group ${\rm GL}(T_a)$ of all linear transformations of the tangent space $T_a$.

The group $\Dgr_k(a)$ is called the {\it differential group of order $k$ at $a\in M$}. 
%
Below for simplicity, we will denote it by $\Dgr_k$.

The natural projection 
$
   \rho_{k,k-1}:\Dgr_k\to\Dgr_{k-1}
$ 
of $k$-jets to $(k-1)$-jets is a group epimorphism. We denote its kernel by $\Delta_k$,
$
  \Delta_k=\{\;[\varphi]_a^k\in\Dgr_k\;|\;[\varphi]_a^{k-1}=[\id]_a^{k-1}\;\}.
$%\begin{lemma} If $k\ge 2$, then the subgroup $\Delta_k\subset\Dgr_k$ and the additive group $S^kT_a^*\otimes T_a$ are naturally isomorphic, 
$
   \Delta_k\simeq S^kT_a^*\otimes T_a.
$  
\end{lemma}\begin{proof} Let $X$ be a vector field on $M$ having zero of order $k$ at the point $a$. Then the mapping $[{\rm exp}X]_a^k\mapsto[X]_a^k$ defines  required isomorphism $\Delta_k\to S^kT_a^*\otimes T_a$. 
\end{proof}%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Geometric structures and differential invariants}%
The bundle $\pi:E(\pi)\to M$ is called {\it natural}, if for every $\varphi\in\Dif$, there is a diffeomorphism $\varphi^{(0)}:E(\pi)\to E(\pi)$ such that the following conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item  $\pi\circ \varphi^{(0)}=\varphi\circ\pi$,
  \item   $(\varphi_1\circ \varphi_2)^{(0)}=\varphi_1^{(0)}\circ \varphi_2^{(0)}$,\;\;$\forall\,\varphi_1,\,\varphi_2\in\Dif$, 
  \item  $\id_M^{(0)}=\id_{E(\pi)}$.
\end{enumerate} 
It follows from these conditions that $\varphi^{(0)}$ is defined uniquely. 

Examples of natural bundles are tangent and cotangent bundles, any tensor bundle and etc. 

A section of natural bundle over $M$ is called a {\it geometric structure on $M$}(see, for example, \cite{Krllv}).

Let $\pi$ be a natural bundle. Then it is defined the natural action of $\Dif$ on geometric structures $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$$$
 \Dif\times\Gamma(\pi)\longrightarrow\Gamma(\pi), \quad (\varphi,s)\mapsto \varphi\!\cdot\! s=\varphi^{(0)}\!\circ\! s\!\circ\!\varphi^{-1}. 
$$
This action generates the lifting of every $\varphi\in \Dif$ to the diffeomorphism $\varphi^{(k)}$ of total space $J^k(\pi)$ by the formula 
$$
   \varphi^{(k)}(\,[s]_a^k\,)=\bigl[\varphi^{(0)}\!\circ\! s\!\circ\!\varphi^{-1}\bigl]_{f(a)}^k,\quad[s]_a^k\in J^k\pi. 
$$  
As a result, the bundle $\pi_k$ with this lifting is a natural bundle. 

It is clear that
$
  \pi_{k,l}\circ \varphi^{(k)}=\varphi^{(l)}\circ\pi_{k,l}\quad\forall\,\varphi\in \Dif.
$
The pseudogroup $\Dif$ acts on every jet bundle $J^k\pi$ by its lifted diffeomorphisms. As a result $J^k\pi$ is divided into orbits of this action.

Let $\theta_k\in J^k\pi$ and let ${\rm Orb(\theta_k)}$ be a $\Dif$-orbit of $\theta_k$. Then ${\rm Orb(\theta_k)}$ is  called a {\it regular orbit} and $\theta_k$ is called a {\it regular point} if $\dim{\rm Orb(\theta_k)}$ is maximal.

Any geometric structure defined on $J^k\pi$ and invariant with respect to the action of $\Dif$ on $J^k\pi$ is called a {\it differential invariant of order $k$  of the bundle $\pi$}.  
In particular, a function on $J^k\pi$ constant on the orbits is called a {\it scalar  differential invariant of order $k$ of $\pi$}.

Let $\Psi$ be a differential invariant of order $k$ of $\pi$ and let $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$. Then the restriction of  $\Psi$ on image $\im j_k(s)$ of section $j_k(s)$ is called the {\it value of $\Psi$ on the section $s$} or {\it differential invariant of order $k$ of geometric structure $s$} and is denoted by $\Psi_s$, 
\begin{equation}\label{InvGmtrStr} 
   \Psi_s=\Psi\circ j_k(s).
\end{equation}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%
Let 
$
   q: S^2(T^*M)\longrightarrow M
$
be the symmetric square of the cotangent bundle $\tau^*:T^*M\to M$. Then sections of this bundle are quadratic differential forms on $M$.

The bundles $J^k q$ are vector and projections $ q_{k,k-1}:J^k\pi\to J^{k-1} q$ give us exact sequences of vector bundles:
$$
   0\to S^k\tau^*\otimes S^2\tau^*\to J^k q\xrightarrow{ q_{k,k-1}} J^{k-1} q\to 0.
$$
The bundle $ q$ is natural. The action of pseudogroup $\Dif$ on the jet bundles $ q_k$ are polynomial along their fibers. Therefore we are in situation described in \cite{KrglkvLchgn}.  

Having in mind the global version of the Lie-Tresse theorem (see \cite{KrglkvLchgn}) we call by a {\it metric invariant of order $k$} a $\Dif$-invariant function on the manifold $J^k q$ which is rational along fibers of $ q_k$.  

It follows from the Lie-Tresse theorem, as well as from the Rosenlicht theorem (see \cite{Rsnlcht}), that such invariants separate regular $\Dif$-orbits in the jet-spaces. 

Remark also that $\Dif$ acts in a transitive way on $M$. Therefore metric invariants are completely defined by their restriction on a fixed fiber $J_a^k q$, where they are $\Dgr_k$-invariant rational functions.

We begin our study of metric invariants from low order jets: $k=0,1$.
For the case $k=0$, the regular orbits are distinguished by the signature of quadratic forms.

%.................................................................................................................\subsection{${\bf \Delta_{k+1}}$-actions}%
For the case $k=1$, the abelian group $\Delta_2\simeq S^2T_a^*\otimes T_a$ acts in transitive way on the fibers $ q_{1,0}^{-1}([g]_a^0)$ over a regular forms $[g]_a^0\in S^2T^*$. 
To analyze in more details $\Delta_{k+1}$-actions, $k=0,1,\ldots$, in fibers of the projection $ q_{k,k-1}$, we denote by $\{\theta_k\}$ a sequence of jets $\theta_k\in J^k q$, $k=0,1,\ldots$, such that $ q_{k,k-1}(\theta_k)=\theta_{k-1}$ and $\theta_0\in S^2T^*$ is a non degenerate quadric.  

Let $X$ be a vector field on $M$ having zero of order $(k+1)$ at the point $a\in M$ and let $\lambda=[X]_a^{k+1}\in S^{k+1}T^*\otimes T$ be its $(k+1)$-jet. Let also $Y$ be a vector field on $M$. Then $k$-jet $\bigl[[Y,X]\bigr]_a^k\in S^kT^*\otimes T$ of the bracket $[Y,X]$ can be found as follows:
$
   \bigl[[Y,X]\bigr]_a^k=Y_a\,\kchrg\delta\lambda,
$ 
where 
$
   \delta: S^{k+1}T^*\otimes T\longrightarrow S^kT^*\otimes T^*\otimes T
$
is the Spencer $\delta$-operator (see \cite{Spncr}) and $\kchrg$ is the hook operator.

Let $g$ be a quadratic differential form on $M$. Then the $k$-jet of Lie derivative $L_X(g)$, 
$
  \Psi=[L_X(g)]_a^k\in S^kT^*\otimes S^2T^*
$
can be computed now as
$
  \Psi(Y_1,Y_2)=g_a(Y_1\,\kchrg\delta\lambda,Y_2)+g_a(Y_1,Y_2\,\kchrg\delta\lambda),
$
where $Y_1,\,Y_2\in T$, $g_a$ is the value of $g$ at the point $a$, and 
$
 g_a(\alpha\otimes Y_1,Y_2)=g_a(Y_1,\alpha\otimes Y_2)=g_a(Y_1,Y_2)\alpha
$
for all $\alpha\in S^kT^*$.

This computation shows that the following result is valid.
%\begin{proposition}\label{OrbtTngntSpc} 
 %\begin{enumerate}
  %\item 
(1) The tangent space to orbit $\Delta_{k+1}(\theta_k)$ coincides with the image of the following operator
$$
   \zeta_{\theta_0}^k=(1\otimes\sym_{\theta_0})\circ \delta :S^{k+1}T^*\otimes T\longrightarrow    S^kT^*\otimes S^2T^*,
$$
where $\sym_{\theta_0} :T^*\otimes T\to S^2T^*$ is the symmetrization operator given by $\theta_0$, i.e. $\sym_{\theta_0}(\sum_jw_j\otimes v_j)=\sum_jw_j\cdot\theta_0(v_j,\cdot)$.
%  \item 
(2) The normal space to the orbit is $\coker\zeta_{\theta_0}^k$.
% \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}\begin{lemma}\label{DeltaS} If $k\geq 1$, then
 $
  \ker\zeta_{\theta_0}^k=0.
$
\end{lemma}\begin{proof} Indeed, if $\zeta_{\theta_0}^k(\Psi)\!=\!0$, then $\delta(\Psi)
\simeq S^kT^*\otimes\so(\theta_0)$.
That is, $\Psi\in\bigl(\so(\theta_0)\bigr)^{(k+1)}$, where by $\bigl(\so(\theta_0)\bigr)^{(i)}$ we denoted the $i$-th prolongation of the Lie algebra $\so(\theta_0)$. 

But $\bigl(\so(\theta_0)\bigr)^{(i)}=0$ for $i\geq 1$, that is $\zeta_{\theta_0}^k$ is injective for $k\geq 1$.
\end{proof}%....................................................................................................................\subsection{Stabilizers}%
Denote by $\St_k\subset\Dgr_{k+1}$ stabilizer of $\theta_k$. Then the last lemma claims that if $k\geq 1$, then $\Delta_{k+1}\cap\St_k=\{e\}$ and projectors $\rho_{k+1,k}:\Dgr_{k+1}\to\Dgr_k$ induce injective group homomorphisms $\St_k\to\St_{k-1}$.

Let $\St_k^0$ be component of unit of the stabilizer $\St_k$.
%\begin{lemma} 
   If $\St_k^0=\{e\}$, $k\geq 1$, then $\St_{k+1}^0=\{e\}$. 
\end{lemma}\begin{proof} One has exact sequence 
$
  0\to\Delta_{k+2}\cap\St_{k+1}^0\subset\St_{k+1}^0
  \xrightarrow{\rho_{k+2,k+1}}\St_k^0. 
$
But from  lemma \ref{DeltaS} we have $\Delta_{k+2}\cap\St_{k+1}^0=\{e\}$. 
\end{proof}%\begin{lemma} Let $n=\dim M\geq 3$, then 
$
  \St_2^0=\{e\}
$ 
for general element $\theta_2\in J_a^2q$.
\end{lemma}\begin{proof}
 First of all we remark that $\St_1^0\stackrel{\rho_{2,1}}{\simeq} \SO(\theta_0)$.

Secondly, the exact sequence 
$
0\to\Delta_3\cap\St_2^0\subset\St_2^0\xrightarrow{\rho_{3,2}}\St_1^0
$
shows that elements $\rho_{3,2}(\St_2^0)$ preserve $\theta_0$ as well as the Ricci operator $R_{\theta_2}$. Therefore, $\St_2^0=\{e\}$, when $n\geq 3$.   
\end{proof}%\begin{corollary} 
$
   \St_k^0=\{e\}
$
for $k\geq 2$ and $n\geq 3$.
\end{corollary}%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Hilbert function of field of metric invariants}%
Let us denote by $\F_k$, $k=2,3,\ldots$, the field of metric invariants of order $\leq k$ and let us consider the integer valued function
$
 {\rm d}: k\longmapsto{\rm tr.deg}\F_k,
$
where ${\rm tr.deg}\F_k$ is the transcendence degree of the field $\F_k$.

Due to the Rosenlicht theorem, ${\rm d}(k)$ is equal to codimension of a  regular orbit and equals also the maximal number of algebraically independent metric invariants of order $\leq k$.

Let 
$
  {\rm H}_n :k\longmapsto{\rm d}(k)-{\rm d}(k-1)
$
be the Hilbert function, which shows the maximal number of independent metric invariants of "pure" order $k$, and $n=\dim(M) $. Then it follows from proposition \ref{OrbtTngntSpc} that
\begin{multline}\label{NumInvrnts0}
 {\rm H}_n(2)=\dim(S^2T_a^*\otimes S^2T_a^*)-\dim(S^3T_a^*\otimes T_a)-\dim\Lambda^2T^*=\\
{n+1\choose 2}^2-n{n+2\choose 3}-{n\choose 2}=\frac{
n(n+3)(n-1)(n-2)}{12}%\frac{n^2(n^2-1)}{12}
\end{multline}
In the case $k\geq 3$, one has
\begin{multline}\label{NumInvrnts1}
 {\rm H}_n(k)=\dim(S^kT_a^*\otimes S^2T_a^*)-\dim(S^{k+1}T_a^*\otimes T_a)=%\\
\frac{n(k-1)}{2}{n+k-1\choose k+1}.
\end{multline}
In the similar way we get for $n=2$\begin{equation}\label{NumInvrnts2}
 {\rm H}_2(2)=1,\quad{\rm H}_2(3)=1,\quad{\rm H}_2(k)=k-1,\; k\geq 4 
\end{equation}%\begin{remark} The last formulae has been obtained in 1892 by Zorawski \cite{Zrwsk} and  formulae for codimensions in the case $n\geq 3$ has been found in 1902 by Haskins \cite{Hskns}. They both used the Sophus Lie method. Namely, they studied the PDE system $X^{(k)}(F)=0$, for invariants $F\in C^{\infty}(J^k q)$, where $X$ is a vector field on $M$ and $X^{(k)}$ its $k$-th prolongation in $J^k q$, and found rank of the system of vector fields of the form $X^{(k)}$ on $J^k q$.
\end{remark}
For small dimensions $(n\leq 4)$ and low orders $k$, we get the following table of values ${\rm H}_n(k)$:\medskip\begin{equation}\label{Tab1} 
\begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$n\diagdown k$ & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 & 9\\
\hline
  2 & 1 & 1 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\
\hline
  3 & 3 & 15 & 27 & 42 & 60 & 71 & 105 & 132\\
\hline
  4 & 14 & 60 & 126 & 224 & 360 & 540 & 770 & 1056\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{equation}\medskip\begin{remark} It is known that the Hilbert function is a polynomial for large values of $k$.
For metric invariants, we see that ${\rm H}_2(k)$ is polynomial for $k\geq 4$ and ${\rm H}_n(k)$, $n\geq 3$, is polynomial for $k\geq 3$.
\end{remark}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%
Below we shortly observe main (and basic) metric invariants.
Denote by $G$ the {\it universal horizontal quadratic form} on the bundle $ q:S^2(T^*M)\to M$.
Universality of $G$ means that restriction of $G $ on a graph of a quadratic differential form $h:M\to S^2(T^*M)$ is equal $h$:
$
  h^*(G)=h.
$%\begin{remark} The above construction of $G$ is completely similar to the construction and definition of the universal Liouville form $\rho$ on the cotangent bundle $T^*M$.
\end{remark}%If we introduce canonical coordinates 
Let $(x^1$,$\ldots$,$u_{ij})$ be the canonical coordinates in bundle $q:S^2(T^*M)\to M$, where $u_{ij}(\theta_0)$ are components of the quadratic form $\theta_0$ in the basis $dx^1$,$\ldots$,$dx^n$, then
$$
  G_{\theta_0}=\sum_{i\leq j}u_{ij}(\theta_0)\,\widehat d x^i\cdot \widehat d x^j\quad\forall\,\theta_0\in S^2(T^*M).
$$%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Basic metric invariants, ${\bf dim M=2}$}\label{BscMtrInv2}%
Let  $M$ be a 2-dimensional manifold, $g$ a (pseudo)-Riemannian metric on M, and $K_g$ its curvature. Then the invariant $K_g$ generates metric invariant of the second order $K$.

The length of the total differential $\widehat d\,K$ gives us the invariant of order 3:
$
  L=G(\widehat d\,K,\widehat d\,K).
$
We say that 4-jet $\theta_4\in J^4 q$ is {\it regular} if 
$
  \widehat d\,K\wedge\widehat d\,L\neq 0
$
at the point $\theta_4$. 
Denote by $\Sigma_4\subset J^4 q$ the set of all {\it singular 4-jets} of $J^4 q$, i.e.  
$$
     \Sigma_4=\{\,\theta_4\in J^4 q\,|\,\bigl(\widehat d\, K\wedge\widehat  d\, L\bigr)|_{\theta_4}=0\,\}. 
$$
On $J^4 q\backslash\Sigma_4$, we write down the universal quadratic form $G$ in coframe $\{ \widehat d\,K,\; \widehat d\,L\}$:
$
   G=G_{11}\widehat d\,K^2+G_{12}\widehat d\,K\cdot\widehat d\,L+G_{22}\widehat d\,L^2,
$
where $G_{ij}$ are metric invariants of order 4.

Metric invariants $K$, $L$, $G_{ij}$, and their Tresse derivatives  
$\displaystyle\frac{D^{l+m}G_{ij}}{D_K^l D_L^m}$ generate all metric differential invariants.

Taking Tresse derivatives
$
 \frac{D G_{ij}}{D_K},\quad \frac{D G_{ij}}{D_L},
$
we get 6 invariants of order 5 and therefore, see table \eqref{Tab1}, we have two syzygies among them.
In order $k=6$, we have 9 invariants 
$
  \frac{D^2G_{ij}}{D_K^l D_L^{2-l}}
$
and therefore 4 syzygies, which one gets by derivations of the previous syzygies. 

From the Lie--Tresse theorem (see \cite{KrglkvLchgn}), we get now  the following description of metric invariants in dimension 2.
%\begin{theorem}
 %\begin{enumerate}
  %\item 
(1) The field of metric invariants is generated by invariants: $K$ of order 2, $L$ of order 3, and invariants $G_{ij}$ of order 4 which are defined on the open set $J^{\infty} q\backslash q_{\infty,4}^{-1}(\Sigma_4)$. 
%  \item 
(2) This field of invariants separates orbits of regular jets.
 % \item 
(3) There are two basic syzygies of order 1 for the basic invariants $K$, $L$,  $G_{ij}$.
%\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}%\begin{remark}
  These syzygies express the fact that the curvature of $G$ equals $K$ and the square of length of its differential is equal to $L$.
\end{remark}%---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The factor equation, ${\bf dim M=2}$}%
Let $g$ be a metric on the 2-dimensio\-nal manifold $M$ and let $K_g$ and $L_g$ be values of the invariants $K$ and $L$ on the metric $g$. 

We say that the metric $g$ is {\it regular at a point}$a\in M$ if the differentials $dK_g$ and $dL_g$ are linear independent at this point, that is 
$ 
   \bigr(dK_g\wedge dL_g\bigl)|_a\neq 0.
$ 
Denote by $\Sigma_g\subset M$ the set of all singular points of $g$, i.e. 
$$
     \Sigma_g=\{\,a\in M\,|\,\bigl(dK_g\wedge d L_g\bigr)|_a=0\,\}. 
$$
The invariants $K_g$ and $L_g$ form invariant coordinate system in a neighborhood of every point $a\in M\backslash\Sigma_g$. 
%
It follows that the metric $g$ can be represented on $M\backslash\Sigma_g$ in the form
\begin{equation}\label{MtrcInvCrdnt1}
  g=(G_{11})_gdK_g^2+(G_{12})_gdK_g\cdot dL_g+(G_{22})_gdL_g^2.
\end{equation}
By a factor equation we mean a system of PDEs such that its solutions are regular orbits of the action of pseudogroup $\Dif$ on metrics on $M$.

 In our case the factor equation is the following system of PDEs
\begin{equation}\label{FctrEqtn1}
  K_h=x^1,\quad L_h=x^2,
\end{equation}
where $x^1, x^2$ are fixed coordinates on $\R^2$ and $h$ is a metric on $\R^2$.   

Assume that $\Sigma_g\neq M$, then the map
$$
  I_g:M\backslash\Sigma_g\longrightarrow\im I_g\subset\R^2,\quad I_g=(K_g, L_g),  
$$
is a covering over the domain $\im I_g$. 
The metric $g$ represented in coordinates $x^1, x^2$ by equation \eqref{MtrcInvCrdnt1} is a multivalued solution of equation \eqref{FctrEqtn1} over the domain $\im I_g$.  
%\begin{theorem} Let $g$ and $\tilde g$ be metrics on $M$ and let    
  $\Sigma_g=\Sigma_{\tilde g}=\emptyset$. Then $g$ and $\tilde g$ are equivalent if and only if $\im I_g=\im I_{\tilde g}$ and their solutions of factor equation \eqref{FctrEqtn1} are the same. 
\end{theorem}%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Basic metric invariants, ${\bf dim M\geq 3}$}%
Let $M$ be an $n$-dimen\-sional, $n\ge 3$, $g$ a (pseudo)-Riemannian metric on $M$, and $\Ric_g$ the Ricci tensor of $g$. 

Let  
$
  R_g:TM\longrightarrow TM 
$ 
be the {\it Ricci operator}(i.e. the linear operator associated with tensor $\Ric_g$).
Functions $(I_1)_g$, $\ldots$, $ (I_n)_g$ defined on $M$ as follows 
\begin{equation}\label{RccInv}
   (I_1)_g=\Tr R_g,\;\ldots,\; (I_n)_g=\Tr R_g^n\quad\forall g\in\Gamma( q)  
\end{equation}
are obviously differential invariants of order 2.   
The corresponding functions on $J^2q$ we denote by $ I_1$, $\ldots$, $ I_n$.

We say that 3-jet $\theta_3\in J^3 q$ is {\it Ricci-regular} if
$
   \bigl(\widehat d\,  I_1\wedge\ldots\wedge\widehat  d\,  I_n\bigr)|_{\theta_3}\neq 0.
$
Denote by $\Sigma_3\subset J^3 q$ the set of all {\it Ricci-singular 3-jets} of $J^3 q$, i.e.  
$$
 \Sigma_3=\{\,\theta_3\in J^3 q\,|\,\bigl(\widehat d\,  I_1\wedge\ldots\wedge\widehat  d\,  I_n\bigr)|_{\theta_3}=0\,\}. 
$$
Note that functions $ I_1$, $\ldots$, $ I_n$ are rational along fibers of the projection $q_2$ and fibers of projection $q_3:\Sigma_3\to m$ are algebraic manifolds.  

On $J^3 q\backslash\Sigma_3$, we write down the universal quadratic form $G$ in coframe $\{\widehat d\, I_1,\ldots,\widehat  d\, I_n\}$:
$
  G=\sum_{1\le i\le j\le n}G_{ij}\,\widehat d\, I_i\cdot\widehat  d\, I_j,
$
where $G_{ij}$ are metric invariants of order 3.

Similar to section \ref{BscMtrInv2}, we construct the Tresse derivatives $D/D_{ I_1}$, $\ldots$, $D/D_{ I_n}$  on $J^{\infty} q\backslash q_{\infty,3}^{-1}(\Sigma_3)$.
Obviously, the metric invariants $ I_1$,$\ldots$,$ I_n$, $G_{ij}$, and all their Tresse derivatives  
$\displaystyle\frac{D^{|\sigma|}G_{ij}}{(D_{ I_1})^{\sigma_1}\cdots (D_{ I_n})^{\sigma_n}}$ 
generate all metric invariants.
From the Lie--Tresse theorem (see \cite{KrglkvLchgn}), we get now  the following statement.
%\begin{theorem}
% \begin{enumerate}
%  \item 
(1) The field of metric invariants is is generated by invariants: $ I_1$, $\ldots$, $ I_n$ of  order 2, and invariants $G_{ij}$ of order 3 which are defined on the open set $J^{\infty} q\backslash q_{\infty,3}^{-1}(\Sigma_3)$. 
%  \item 
(2) This field of invariants separates orbits of Ricci-regular jets.
% \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}%---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The factor equation, ${\bf dim M\geq 3}$.}%
Let $g$ be a metric on $M$, $\dim M\geq 3$, and $ (I_1)_g$,$\ldots$, $ (I_n)_g$ be  values of the invariants $ I_1$,$\ldots$,$ I_n$ on $g$.

We say that the metric $g$ is {\it Ricci-regular at a point}$a\in M$ if the differentials $d (I_1)_g$,$\ldots$,$d (I_n)_g$ are linear independent at this point, that is 
$ 
   \bigr(d (I_1)_g\wedge\ldots\wedge d (I_n)_g\bigl)|_a\neq 0.
$ 
Denote by $\Sigma_g\subset M$ the set of all {\it Ricci-singular points} of $g$, i.e. 
$$
     \Sigma_g=\{\,a\in M\,|\,\bigl(d (I_1)_g\wedge\ldots\wedge d  (I_n)_g\bigr)|_a=0\,\}. 
$$
The invariants $ (I_1)_g$,$\ldots$, $ (I_n)_g$ form invariant coordinate system in a neighborhood of every point $a\in M\backslash\Sigma_g$. 
%
It follows that the metric $g$ can be represented on $M\backslash\Sigma_g$ in the form
\begin{equation}\label{MtrcInvCrdnt2}
  g=\sum_{1\le i\le j\le n}(G_{ij})_g\,d (I_i)_g\cdot d (I_j)_g,.
\end{equation}
Let $x^1$, $\ldots$, $x^n$ be fixed coordinates on $\R^n$ and let $h$ be a metric on $\R^n$, then the factor equation is the following system of PDEs.
\begin{equation}\label{FctrEqtn2}
  (I_1)_h=x^1,\quad\ldots,\quad (I_n)_h=x^n.
\end{equation}
Assume that $\Sigma_g\neq M$, then the map
$$
  I_g:M\backslash\Sigma_g\longrightarrow\im I_g\subset\R^n,\quad 
I_g=\bigl( (I_1)_g, \ldots,  (I_n)_g\bigr),  
$$
is a covering over the domain $\im I_g$. 
The metric $g$ represented in coordinates $x^1$, $\ldots$, $x^n$ by  \eqref{MtrcInvCrdnt2} is a multivalued solution of equation \eqref{FctrEqtn2} over the domain $\im I_g$.  
%\begin{theorem}\label{ThrmClMtr} Let $g$ and $\tilde g$ be metrics on $M$ and let    
  $\Sigma_g=\Sigma_{\tilde g}=\emptyset$. Then $g$ and $\tilde g$ are equivalent if and only if $\im I_g=\im I_{\tilde g}$ and their solutions of factor equation \eqref{FctrEqtn2} are the same. 
\end{theorem}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%
Let $M$ be an oriented 4-dimensional manifold, $g$ a Lorentzian metric on $M$, and $\Ric_g$ the Ricci tensor of $g$.

The {\it (vacuum) Einstein equation} is the following system of 10 quasilinear 2-order PDEs on 10 independent components of $g$\begin{equation}\label{VcmEnstnEq}
\Ric_g-\Lambda g=0,
\end{equation}
where $\Lambda$ is the cosmological constant. 
Solutions of this equation are called {\it Einstein metrics}.

Let $ q: S^2(T^*M)\to M$ be, as above, the symmetric square of the cotangent bundle $\tau^*:TM^*\to M$ and let
$
  \E_2\subset J^2 q
$
be the submanifold  corresponding equation \eqref{VcmEnstnEq}.
Denote by $\E_k=\E_2^{(k-2)}\subset J^k q$, $k=2,3,\ldots$, prolongations of $\E_2$. 
By $\Sol(\E_2)$ we denote the set of all solutions of equation \eqref{VcmEnstnEq}.
Equations $\E_2$ as well as $\E_k$ are invariant with respect to the pseudogroup $\Dif$.  

Remark that the fibers $\E_{k,a}\subset J_a^k q$ of the projection $ q_k:\E_k\to M$ are irreducible algebraic manifolds. 

%---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Relativistic invariants}%
We say that a function $I$ defined on an open and dense subset of $\E_k$ is a {\it relativistic invariant of order $k$} if 
\begin{enumerate}
 \item $I$ is a rational function along fibers of the projection $ q_k:\E_k\to M$ and
 \item $I$ is invariant under the prolonged action of $\Dif$ on $\E_k$.
\end{enumerate}
The Lie--Tresse theorem (see \cite{KrglkvLchgn}) describes the possible structure of the field of relativistic invariants and claims that they do separate regular orbits in the jet spaces. 
Remark that for Einstein metrics their metric invariants \eqref{RccInv} are constants therefore Einstein metrics corresponds to singular cases for classification given in theorem \ref{ThrmClMtr}.

Let us take an Einstein metric $g$ and consider its {\it Weyl tensor}(represented as a linear operator)
$
  W_g: \Lambda^2T^*\longrightarrow \Lambda^2T^*.
$ 
 It is known  that the Hodge operator $*:\Lambda^2T^*\to\Lambda^2T^*$ defines a complex structure on the vector space $\Lambda^2T^*$, i.e. $*^2=-1$, and
the operators $W_g$ and $*$ commute (\cite{Bss}).  
Hence $W_g$ might be considered as the $\C$-linear operator.  In addition this 
operator satisfies the condition $\Tr_{\C}W_g=0$.

Let 
\begin{equation}\label{WlInv}
  \Tr_{\C} W_g^2=  (I_1)_g+i (I_2)_g,\quad \Tr_{\C} W_g^3=  (I_3)_g+i (I_4)_g.
\end{equation}
Then $ (I_1)_g$, $ (I_2)_g$, $ (I_3)_g$, $ (I_4)_g$ are differential invariants of $g$ of order 2.    

Denote by $ I_1$, $\ldots$, $ I_4$ corresponding rational functions on $\E_2$.
We say that 3-jet $\theta_3\in\E_3$ is {\it Weyl-regular} if
$$
   \bigl(\widehat d\,  I_1\wedge\ldots\wedge\widehat  d\,  I_4\bigr)|_{\theta_3}\neq 0.
$$
Denote by $\Sigma_3\subset\E_3$ the set of all {\it Weyl-singular 3-jets} of $\E_3$, i.e.  
$$
 \Sigma_3=\{\,\theta_3\in\E_3\,|\,\bigl(\widehat d\,  I_1\wedge\ldots\wedge\widehat d\,  I_4\bigr)|_{\theta_3}=0\,\}. 
$$
Note that fibers of the projection $ q_3:\Sigma_3\to M$ are algebraic manifolds.  

On $\E_3\backslash\Sigma_3$, we write down the universal quadratic form $G$ in coframe $\{\widehat d\, I_1$, $\ldots$, $\widehat  d\, I_4\}$:
$
  G=\sum_{1\le i\le j\le 4}G_{ij}\,\widehat d\, I_i\cdot\widehat  d\, I_j,
$
where $G_{ij}$ are relativistic invariants of order 3.
In the same way as in section \ref{BscMtrInv2}, we construct the Tresse derivatives $D/D_{ I_1}$, $\ldots$, $D/D_{ I_4}$ on $\E_{\infty}\backslash q_{\infty,3}^{-1}(\Sigma_3)$.
Obviously, the relativistic invariants $ I_1$,$\ldots$,$ I_4$, $G_{ij}$, and all their Tres\-se derivatives generate all relativistic invariants.

From the global Lie--Tresse theorem (\cite{KrglkvLchgn}), we get now  the following statement.
%\begin{theorem}
% \begin{enumerate}
 % \item 
(1) The field of relativistic invariants is  generated by invariants: $ I_1$, $\ldots$, $ I_4$ of  order 2,  and invariants $G_{ij}$ of order 3 which are 
defined on the open set $\E_{\infty}\backslash q_{\infty,3}^{-1}(\Sigma_3)$. 

%  \item 
(2) These invariants separate orbits of Weyl-regular jets.
% \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Einstein factor equation.}%
We say that an Einstein metric $g$ is {\it Weyl-regular at a point}$a\in M$ if the differentials $d (I_1)_g$, $\ldots$, $d (I_4)_g$ are linear independent at this point, i.e. 
\begin{equation}\label{RglrPnt3}
   \bigr(d (I_1)_g\wedge\ldots\wedge d (I_4)_g\bigl)|_a\neq 0.
\end{equation}
Denote by $\Sigma_g\subset M$ the set of all {\it Weyl-singular} points of $g$, i.e. 
$$
 \Sigma_g=\{\,a\in M\,|\,\bigr(d (I_1)_g\wedge\ldots\wedge d (I_4)_g\bigl)|_a=0\,\}. 
$$
Then invariants $ (I_1)_g$, $\ldots$, $ (I_4)_g$ form invariant coordinate system in a neighborhood of every point $a\in M\backslash\Sigma_g$. 
%
and the metric $g$ can be represented on $M\backslash\Sigma_g$ in the form
\begin{equation}\label{MtrcInvCrdnt3} 
  g=\sum_{1\le i\le j\le 4}(G_{ij})_g\,d\,(I_i)_g\cdot d\, (I_j)_g,
\end{equation} 
where $(G_{ij})_g$ are differential invariants of $g$ of order 3.

Let $z^1$, $z^2$ be fixed coordinates on the complex plane $\C^2$ and let $h$ be a Lorentzian metric on $\C^2$ considered as a 4-dimensional real manifold.  
We call by Einstein factor equation the following system of PDEs on the metric $h$\begin{equation}\label{EnstnFctrEqtn}
  \Ric_h-\lambda h=0,\quad\Tr_{\C}W_h^2=z_1,\quad\Tr_{\C}W_h^3=z_2.
\end{equation}
Assume that $\Sigma_g\neq M$, then the map
\begin{gather*} 
  I_g:M\backslash\Sigma_g\longrightarrow\im I_g\subset\C^2,\\ 
I_g=\bigl((I_1)_g+i\,(I_2)_g,\;(I_3)_g+i\,(I_4)_g)\bigr),  
\end{gather*} 
is a covering over the domain $\im I_g$. 
The metric $g$ written in coordinates $z^1, z^2, \bar z^1, \bar z^2$ by equation \eqref{MtrcInvCrdnt3} is a multivalued solution of equation \eqref{EnstnFctrEqtn} over the domain $\im I_g$.  
%\begin{theorem} Let $g, \tilde g\in\Sol(\E)$ and let    
  $\Sigma_g=\Sigma_{\tilde g}=\emptyset$. Then $g$ and $\tilde g$ are equivalent if and only if $\im I_g=\im I_{\tilde g}$ and their solutions of the Einstein factor equation coincide. 
\end{theorem}%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Hilbert function for the field of relativistic invariants}%
Let $\RltvInv_k$ be the field of relativistic invariants of order $\leq k$. Then due to the Rosenlicht theorem (\cite{Rsnlcht}) transcendence degree ${\rm tr.deg}\RltvInv_k$ of $\RltvInv_k$ is equal to codimension of a regular orbit in $\E
_k$. 

To find these codimensions, we take a sequence $\theta_l\in\E_l$, $l=0,1,\ldots$, such that $ q_{l+1,l}(\theta_{l+1})=\theta_l$, $l\geq 0$, and $\theta_0$ is a Lorentzian metric.
Denote by $\g_k\subset S^k(T^*M)\otimes S^2(T^*M)$ symbols of prolongations $\E_k$ at points $\theta_k$, $k=2,3,\ldots$
We assume that $\E_1=J^1 q$ and $\E_0=J^0 q$, so $\g_1=T^*M\otimes S^2(T^*M)$ and $\g_0=S^2(T^*M)$.

First of all we note that similar to proposition \ref{OrbtTngntSpc}, we have the following description of tangents to orbits $\Delta_{k+1}(\theta_k)\subset\E_k$ of elements $\theta_k\in\E_k$.
%\begin{proposition}\label{OrbtTngntSpc1}
%\begin{enumerate}
%   \item 
(1) The tangent space to orbit $\Delta_{k+1}(\theta_k)\subset\E_k$ at the point $\theta_k\in\E_k$ coincides with the image of the following operator:
$
  \zeta_{\theta_0}^k: S^{k+1}T^*\otimes T^*\longrightarrow \g_k.
$
%   \item 

(2) The normal space $\nu_k$ at the point $\theta_k$ to the orbit is the co-kernel of $\zeta_{\theta_0}^k$:
$
  \nu_k=\g_k/\im\zeta_{\theta_0}^k.
$ 
% \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
To find dimension of $\g_k$ we consider the Einstein complex (see \cite{LchYum} for details)
$ 
  0\to\Omega^1\xrightarrow{\Lch}\Sigma^2\xrightarrow{l(\E)}
  \Sigma^2\xrightarrow{\B}\Omega^1\to 0
$ 
where $l(\E)$ is a linearization of the Einstein operator and $B$ is a Bianchi operator. 
It can be shown (see \cite{Krglkv} and \cite{LchYum}) that the corresponding symbolic sequences 
$$ 
   S^kT^*\otimes S^2T^*
\xrightarrow{\sigma_{\E}^{(k-2)}} S^{k-2}T^*\otimes S^2T^*
  \xrightarrow{\sigma_{B}^{(k-1)}}  S^{k-3}T^*\otimes T^*\to 0
$$ 
is exact, when $k\geq 2$.
Therefore,
$$
 \dim\g_k=10{k+3\choose 3}-10{k+1\choose 3}+4{k\choose 3}=\frac23(k+3)(k^2+9k+5)
$$
and
$
   \dim\nu_k=2(k+3)(k-1),
$
when $k\geq 2$.
\medskip
Remark that $\St_2(\theta_2)=\{e\}$ for a generic point $\theta_2\in\E_2$. 
Indeed, there is a base $\omega_1$, $\omega_2$, $\omega_3$, in $\Lambda^2T_a^*$ such that $\omega_i\wedge\omega_j=0$ for all $i,j=1,2,3$. Therefore each 2-form $\omega_i$ defines a two-dimensional plane $\Pi_i\subset T_a$.
Moreover, $\Pi_i\cap\Pi_j\neq 0$ if $i\neq j$. 
Hence on each plane $\Pi_i$, say $\Pi_1$, planes $\Pi_2$ and $\Pi_3$ defines two directions: $\Pi_1\cap\Pi_2$ and $\Pi_1\cap\Pi_3$. 
Thus elements $\St_2^0(\theta_2)$ are elements of ${\rm SO(\theta_0)}$ which preserve every plane $\Pi_i$ and these two directions. 
Hence $\St_2^0(\theta_2)=\{e\}$, for generic point $\theta_2\in\E_2$.

Denote by ${\rm H}_{\E}$ the Hilbert function for the field of relativistic invariants:
$
  {\rm H}_{\E}:k\longmapsto{\rm tr.deg}\RltvInv_k-\,{\rm tr.deg}\RltvInv_{k-1}.
$ 
One has 
$
 {\rm H}_{\E}(2)=\dim\nu_2-\dim{\rm o}(1,3)=4.
$
In order 2, we have 4 invariants  defined by the Weyl tensor $W: \Lambda^2T^*\to \Lambda^2T^*$.
Namely,
$$
 I_1={\rm Re}\Tr_{\C} W^2,\; I_2={\rm Re}\Tr_{\C} W^3,\;
  I_3={\rm Im}\Tr_{\C} W^2,\; I_4={\rm Im}\Tr_{\C} W^3.
$$
Their total differentials 
$
  \widehat d I_1,\;\widehat d I_2,\;\widehat d I_3,\;\widehat d I_4
$
define the invariant co-frame on a Zariski open subset in $J^3 q$. 
Therefore stabilizers of $\theta_k$, $k\geq 2$ are trivial and 
$
  {\rm H}_{\E}(k)=\dim\nu_k=2(k+3)(k-1),
$
for $k\geq 3$.

As a corollary we get the following table of numbers of independent relativistic invariants of pure order $k$ for small values $k$\medskip\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$k$ & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 & 9\\
\hline
${\rm H}_{\E}$ & 4 & 24 & 42 & 64 & 90 & 120 & 154 & 192 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Poincare function for the field of relativistic invariants}%
Consider the Poincare function for the field of relativistic invariants
$
  {\rm P}_{\E}(t)=\sum_{k\geq 0}{\rm H}_{\E}(k)t^k.
$
It is easy to show that
$
  {\rm P}_{\E}(t)=\frac{2t^2(3t^3-9t^2+6t+2)}{(1-t)^3}.
$%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Einstein--Maxwell equation}%
Let as in previous section $M$ be an oriented 4-dimensional manifold, $g$ be a Lorentzian metric on $M$, and $\Ric_g$ be the Ricci tensor of $g$. 
By $f$ we denote a differential 2-form on $M$.  

The {\it Einstein--Maxwell equation (in the absence of current)} is the following system of 18 PDEs on 10 components of $g$ and 6 components of $f$(see, for example \cite{LndLfshts}, \cite{CrtsMllr}).
\begin{equation}\label{EnstnMxwllEq}
     \Ric_g-\Lambda\,g-\frac{8 \pi k}{c^4}\Emt(f)=0,\quad
     d\,f=0,\quad
     d\,*\,f =0,
\end{equation}
where $\Lambda$ and $k$ are cosmological and gravitational constants   respectively and $c$ is the velocity of light,
$$
\Emt(f)_{ij}=\frac{1}{4 \pi}\bigl(-f_{im}f_{j\;\cdot}^{\;\;m}
+\frac14g_{ij}f_{mn}f^{mn}\bigr).
$$
Two last equations of system \eqref{EnstnMxwllEq} are called  the {\it Maxwell equation}. A 2-form $f$ satisfying the Maxwell equation is called an {\it electromagnetic} or a {\it Faraday tensor}; the tensor $\Emt(f)$ is called the {\it energy-momentum tensor of electromagnetic field $f$}. 
The Maxwell equation can be equivalently rewritten in terms of the 4-potenti\-al as follows 

\begin{remark} There exists (at least locally) a differential 1-form $A$ on $M$ such that $d A=f$.  This form is called {\rm 4-potential of $f$}.
$ 
  d\,*\,d\,A=0.
$
\end{remark}
Let
$$
  \xi  %\tau^{(0,2)}
:T^{0,2}(M)=S^2(T^*M)\oplus\Lambda^2(T^*M)\longrightarrow M 
$$
be the bundle of (0,2)-tensors on M. 
Let  
$
  \EM_2\subset J^2\xi
$
be the submanifold corresponding to equation \eqref{EnstnMxwllEq} and let 
$\EM_k=\EM_2^{(k-2)}\subset J^k\xi $, $k=2,3,\ldots,\infty$, be prolongations of the equation $\EM_2$.
Note that the equation $\EM_2$ is formally integrable (\cite{Krglkv}) and fibers of projection $\xi_2:\EM_2\to M$ are irreducible algebraic manifolds  (\cite{KrglkvLchgn}).  
As above, we denote by $\Sol(\EM_2)$ the set of all solutions of equation \eqref{EnstnMxwllEq}.
The prolongations $\EM_k$ are invariant with respect to pseudogroup \linebreak$\Dif$.

%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{Basic relativistic electromagnetic invariants.}%
We say that a function $I$ defined on an open and dense subset of $\EM_k$ is a {\it relativistic electromagnetic invariant of order $k$} if 
\begin{enumerate}
 \item $I$ is a rational function along fibers of the projection $ \xi_k:\EM_k\to M$ and
 \item $I$ is invariant under the prolonged action of $\Dif$ on $\EM_k$.
\end{enumerate}
The Lie--Tresse theorem (\cite{KrglkvLchgn}) describes the possible structure of the field of relativistic electromagnetic invariants and claims that they separate orbits of regular jets. 

%....................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Basic invariants of order 0}%
Let $s=(g,f)$ be an arbitrary solution of equation \eqref{EnstnMxwllEq}. 
Then it generates the morphism of vector bundles
$
   \widehat f_s:TM\longrightarrow TM
$
by the formula
$
  \widehat f_s(v)=g^{-1}\bigl(f(v,\cdot)\bigr),\; \forall\,v\in TM.
$
Let $\widehat f_s^*$ be a conjugate operator for $\widehat f_s$ with respect to the metric $g$. Then 
$
   \widehat f_s^*=-\widehat f_s
$
and therefore the characteristic polynomial  for $\widehat f_s$ has the form
$
   \lambda^4+(I_1)_s\,\lambda^2+(I_2)_s,
$
where functions $(I_1)_s$ and $(I_2)_s$ are differential invariants of order 0 of the solution $s$.
These invariants of solutions define relativistic electromagnetic invariant $I_1$ and $I_2$  of order $0$ on $J^0 \xi$ by formula \eqref{InvGmtrStr}.

%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Invariant subspaces.}%
In this subsection, we briefly reproduce so\-me facts from \cite{Rnch}.

Let $\{e_1, e_2, e_3, e_4\}$ be an orthonormal base in $T_a$ with respect to the metric $g$ such that $|e_1|=-1$ and $|e_2|=|e_3|=|e_4|=1$. Then one can get by direct calculations that the operator $\widehat f_s|_{T_a}$ has the following matrix in this base
\begin{equation}\label{MtrxFrdOpr0}   
\widehat f_s|_{T_a}=  
  \begin{pmatrix}
   0          & \alpha      & \beta          & \gamma\\
   \alpha   & 0             & \delta          & \epsilon\\
   \beta     & -\delta     & 0                & \varepsilon\\
   \gamma & -\epsilon & -\varepsilon & 0
  \end{pmatrix}.
\end{equation}  
A 2-dimensional subspace of the tangent space $T_a$ is called {\it hyperbolic} or {\it elliptic} if it intersects the light cone respectively by two directions or in the zero-point only. 

We denote a hyperbolic subspace and an elliptic one as $H_a$ and $E_a$ respectively.
It is clear that the operator $\widehat f_s|_{T_a}$ has at least one an invariant 2-dimensional subspace $L\subset T_a$. 
There are three cases: 1) $L=H_a$,  2) $L=E_a$, and 3) $L$ contains zero-directions.

In the first case, one can choose orthonormal base $\{e_1,e_2\}$ in $H_a$ with $|e_1|=-1$, $|e_2|=1$. Take an orthonormal base $\{e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4\}$ in $T_a$. In this base, the operator $\widehat f_s|_{T_a}$ has form  \eqref{MtrxFrdOpr0}. Taking into account that $H_a$ is invariant plane of $\widehat f_s$, we get 
$\beta =\gamma=\delta=\epsilon=0$. 
Hence, 
\begin{equation}\label{MtrxFrdOpr1}   
 \widehat f_s|_{T_a}=  
  \begin{pmatrix}
   0        & \alpha & 0                  & 0\\
   \alpha & 0        & 0                  & 0\\
   0         & 0       & 0                   & \varepsilon\\
   0         & 0       & -\varepsilon    & 0
  \end{pmatrix}.
\end{equation}  
It is clear that
$
   T_a=H_a\oplus E_a,\quad H_a\perp E_a,
$
where $E_a=\langle e_3, e_4\rangle$ and 
\begin{equation}\label{Invrnts0}   
  (I_1)_s(a)=\varepsilon(a)^2-\alpha(a)^2,\quad   
  (I_2)_s(a)=\bigl(\,\alpha(a)\varepsilon(a)\,\bigr)^2.
\end{equation}  
Moreover, the condition  
$
   (I_1)_s(a)\neq 0$ or $(I_2)_s(a)\neq 0, 
$
is equivalent to $f|_{T_a}\neq 0$.

In the second case, one can choose orthonormal base $\{e_3,e_4\}$ in $E_a$ with $|e_3|=|e_4|=1$. Taking an orthonormal base $\{e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4\}$ in $T_a$, we get that the operator $\widehat f_s|_{T_a}$ in this base has matrix \eqref{MtrxFrdOpr1} and the invariants $(I_1)_s(a)$ and $(I_2)_s(a)$ are defined by \eqref{Invrnts0}.

In the case when $L$ contains zero-directions and the operator $\widehat f_s|_{T_a}$ has no 2-dimensional invariant subspaces with two zero-directions or without zero-directions, it can be found an orthonormal base $\{e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4\}$ in $T_a$(\cite{Rnch}) such that
$$ 
 \widehat f_s|_{T_a}=  
  \begin{pmatrix}
   0 & 0    &  \eta & 0\\
   0 & 0    &  \eta & 0\\
    \eta & - \eta  & 0  & 0\\
   0 &   0  & 0  & 0
  \end{pmatrix}.
$$  
In this case 
$
  (I_1)_s(a)= 0\quad\text{and}\quad (I_2)_s(a)= 0.
$
Thus we have the following 
%\begin{proposition}\label{ExstHprbEllptDstrb} The condition
$
  \bigl(\;(I_1)_s(a),\; (I_2)_s(a)\;\bigr)\neq 0
$
is necessary and sufficient for existence an invariant hyperbolic subspace $H_a\subset T_a$ and an invariant elliptic subspace $E_a\subset T_a$ such that 
$
   T_a=H_a\oplus E_a$ and $ H_a\perp E_a. 
$
\end{proposition}%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Rainich 0-singular points}%
We say that a {\it solution $s\in\Sol(\EM_2)$ is Rainich 0-regular at a point $a\in M$} if 
\begin{equation}\label{Rnch0}  
  (I_1)_s(a)\neq 0\quad\text{or}\quad (I_2)_s(a)\neq 0.
\end{equation}  
By $R_s^0$, we denote the set of all Rainich 0-singular points of $s$,
$$
   R_s^0=\{\;a\in M\;|\;(I_1)_s(a)=0\;\text{and}\;(I_2)_s(a)=0\;\}.
$$
Proposition \ref{ExstHprbEllptDstrb} shows that on the complement $M\setminus R_s^0$, we have hyperbolic and elliptic distributions:
$$
  H:a\longmapsto H_a\quad\text{and}\quad E:a\longmapsto E_a,\quad\forall\, a\in M\setminus R_s^0.
$$ 
Restricting differentials $d(I_1)_s$ and $d(I_2)_s$ on the distributions $H$ and $E$, we get differential 1-forms
$$
e_s^1=d(I_1)_s|_H,\; e_s^2=d(I_2)_s|_H,\; e_s^3=d(I_1)_s|_E,\; 
e_s^4=d(I_2)_s|_E.
$$
These differential 1-forms are invariants of order 1 of the solution $s$. 

We say that a {\it  0-jet $\theta_0\in J^0 \xi$ is Rainich 0-singular} if 
$
  I_1(\theta_0)= 0$ and $I_2(\theta_0)= 0.
$
Denote by $R_0\subset J^0\xi$ the set of all  Rainich 0-singular 0-jets. 
Remark that fibers of the projection $ \xi:R_0\to M$ are algebraic manifolds.  
The defined above differential 1-forms $e_s^1$,$\ldots$,$e_s^4$ generate invariant horizontal differential 1-forms 
$ 
   e^1,\;\ldots,\;e^4
$ 
on $J^1 \xi\setminus( \xi_{1,0})^{-1}(R_0)$. 

%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Rainich 1-singular points}%
We say that a solution  $s\in\Sol(\EM_2)$ is {\it Rainich 1-singular at a point $a\in M\setminus R_s^0$} if 
\begin{equation}\label{Rnch1}  
  \bigl( e_s^1\wedge e_s^2\bigr)|_a= 0\quad\text{or}\quad
\bigl(e_s^3\wedge e_s^4\bigr)|_a= 0.
\end{equation}  
By $R_s^1$, we denote the set of all Rainich 1-singular points of $s$.
The 1-forms $e_s^i$ define the invariant coframe $\{e_s^1,\ldots,e_s^4\}$ on the open subset $(M\setminus R_s^0)\setminus R_s^1$. 
This coframe generates in the natural way the dual frame 
$\{(e_1)_s$, $\ldots$, $(e_4)_s\}$. 

We say that 1-jet $\theta_1\in J^1 \xi\setminus( \xi_{1,0})^{-1}(R_0)$ is {\it Rainich 1-singular} if
$
  (e^1\wedge e^2)_{\theta_1}=0$ or $(e^3\wedge e^4)_{\theta_1}=0. 
$
Denote by $R_1$ the set of all Rainich 1-singular 1-jets. 
Note that fibers of $R_1$ are algebraic manifolds too.
We say that elements of $\EM_k$ are {\it Rainich regular} if their projections do not belong to $R_1$ and $R_0$.
Horizontal 1-forms $e^1$, $\ldots$, $e^4$ define invariant coframe on the manifold of regular jets. The dual frame $\{e_1,\ldots,e_4\}$ consists of four invariant derivations.

%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Basic invariants of order 1}%
Let $G$ be universal horizontal quadratic form on the bundle $S^2(T^*M)\to M$ and let $F$ be the {\it universal horizontal exterior 2-form} on the bundle $\Lambda^2(T^*M)\to M$. 
Then the pair $(G, F)$ is {\it universal} on the bundle $  \xi:T^{0,2}M\to M$, in the sense that
$
  s^*(G,F)=s$ for any $s\in\Gamma( \xi).
$
In regular jets, we write down the universal pair $(G,F)$ in coframe $\{e^1$,$\ldots$, $e^4\}$ as follows
$$
  (G,F)=\Bigl(\sum_{1\le i\le j\le 4}G_{ij}\,e^i\cdot e^j,\;
\sum_{1\le i < j\le 4}F_{ij}\, e^i\wedge e^j\;\Bigr),
$$
where $G_{ij}$ and $F_{ij}$ are relativistic invariants of order 1.
Obviously, the relativistic invariants $I_1$,$I_2$, $G_{ij}$, $F_{ij}$, and all their derivatives along invariant derivatives $e_i$  
generate all relativistic electromagnetic invariants.

From the global Lie--Tresse theorem (\cite{KrglkvLchgn}), we get now  the following statement.
%\begin{theorem}
% \begin{enumerate}
%  \item 
(1) The field of relativistic electromagnetic invariants is generated by invariants: $I_1$, $I_2$ of  order 0, invariants $G_{ij}$, $F_{ij}$ of order 1, and the invariant derivatives, which are defined on the open set of  Rainich regular jets.

%  \item 
(2) The field separates orbits of Rainich regular jets.
% \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}%\begin{remark}
  It is easy to see that invariants $I_1$ and $I_2$ might be expressed in terms of $G_{ij}$ and $F_{ij}$. 
\end{remark}%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Einstein--Maxwell factor equation.}%
Let $x^1$,$\ldots$,$x^4$ be fixed coordinates on $\R^4$ and let $J=(J_1,J_2,J_3,J_4)$ be four independent relativistic electromagnetic invariants. 

Under the Einstein--Maxwell factor equation, we understand the following system of PDEs
\begin{equation}\label{EMFctrEqtn}
\left\{\begin{aligned}
  &\Ric_h-\lambda h-\frac{8 \pi k}{c^4}\Emt(\varphi)=0,\quad d\varphi=0,\quad d*\varphi=0,\\ 
  & (J_1)_r=x_1,\quad  (J_2)_r=x_2,\quad  (J_1)_r=x_3,\quad  (J_4)_r=x_4\\
\end{aligned}\right.
\end{equation}
for the pair $r=(h,\varphi)$, where $h$ is a Lorentzian metric on $\R^4$ and $\varphi$ is an exterior differential 2-form on  $\R^4$.

Let $s$ be a solution of  the Einstein--Maxwell equation. We say that $s$ is $J$-singular at $a\in M$ if 
$
  \bigl(d(J_1)_s\wedge d(J_2)_s\wedge d(J_3)_s\wedge d(J_4)_s\bigr)|_a=0
$
Let $\Sigma_s\subset M$ be the set of all $J$-singular points of solution $s$. Then the map 
$$
  J_s: M\setminus\Sigma_s\longrightarrow\R^4,\quad J_s=\bigl((J_1)_s,(J_2)_s,(J_3)_s,(J_4)_s\bigr)
$$
is a covering over domain $\im J_s$ and solution $s$ written in terms of coordinates $x^1$,$\ldots$,$x^4$$$
  s=\bigl(\,(\tilde G_{ij})_s d(J_i)_s\cdot d(J_j)_s,\;(\tilde F_{ij})_s d(J_i)_s\wedge d(J_j)_s\;\bigr)
$$ 
is a multivalued solution of factor equation \eqref{EMFctrEqtn}. 
%\begin{theorem} Let $s, \tilde s\in\Sol(\EM)$ and let    
  $\Sigma_s=\Sigma_{\tilde s}=\emptyset$. Then $s$ and $\tilde s$ are equivalent if and only if $\im J_s=\im J_{\tilde s}$ and their solutions of the Einstein--Maxwell factor equation are the same. 
\end{theorem}%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Hilbert function for the field of relativistic electromagnetic invariants}%
At first we describe symbols of the Maxwell equations taking in two different forms:
\begin{equation}\label{Mxwll1}
  d*dA=0,\quad A\in\Omega^1,
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation}\label{Mxwll2}
  dF=0,\quad d*F=0,\quad F\in\Omega^2 
\end{equation}%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Symbols of the Maxwell equations in form \eqref{Mxwll1}}%
Symbols $\g_k^A\subset S^k(T*M)\otimes T^*M$ are kernels of the following operators
\begin{multline*}
  S^k(T^*M)\otimes T^*M\xrightarrow{\delta} S^{k-1}(T^*M)\otimes\Lambda^2(T^*M)\xrightarrow{*}\\S^{k-1}(T^*M)\otimes\Lambda^2(T^*M) \xrightarrow{\delta}
S^{k-2}(T^*M)\otimes\Lambda^3(T^*M)
\end{multline*}
when $k\geq 2$, and
$
   \g_0^A=T^*M,\quad \g_1^A=T^*M\otimes T^*M.
$
The Spencer $\delta$-complex
$$
 0\to \g_3^A\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_2^A\otimes T^*M\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_1^A\otimes\Lambda^2 (T^*M)\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_0^A\otimes\Lambda^3(T^*M)\to 0
$$
has 1-dimensional cohomology at the term $g_1^A\otimes\Lambda^2 (T^*M)$(see \cite{Krglkv}).
Taking the Euler characteristic of the complex, we get
$$
 \dim\g_3^A-4\dim\g_2^A+6\dim\g_1^A-4\dim\g_0^A=1,
$$ 
or
$
  \dim\g_3^A=65.
$
It is proved in \cite{Krglkv} that the $\delta$-complex 
\begin{multline}\label{kDltCmplx}
0\to \g_k^A\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_{k-1}^A\otimes T^*M\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_{k-2}^A\otimes\Lambda^2 (T^*M)\xrightarrow{\delta}\\
\g_{k-3}^A\otimes\Lambda^3(T^*M)
\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_{k-4}^A\otimes\Lambda^4(T^*M)\to 0
\end{multline}
is exact if $k\geq 4$.

Let ${\rm H}^A(k)=\dim\g_k^A$ be the Hilbert function of Maxwell equations \eqref{Mxwll1}.
It follows from \eqref{kDltCmplx} that ${\rm H}^A(k)$ satisfies the following recurrence relation
$$
 {\rm H}^A(k)=4{\rm H}^A(k-1)-6{\rm H}^A(k-2)+4{\rm H}^A(k-3)-{\rm H}^A(k-4)
$$
with initial data
$
  {\rm H}^A(0)=4,\quad{\rm H}^A(1)=16,\quad{\rm H}^A(2)=36,\quad{\rm H}^A(3)=65.
$
Therefore,
$
  {\rm H}^A(k)=\frac16(k+2)(k^2+9k+12).
$%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Symbols of the Maxwell equations in form \eqref{Mxwll2}}%
Consider Max\-well equations in form \eqref{Mxwll2}. Then symbols $\g_k^F\subset S^k(T^*M)\otimes\Lambda^2(T^*M)$ of this system are images of the symbols $\g_k^A$ under the Spencer operator
$$
\delta :S^{k+1}(T^*M)\otimes T^*M\longrightarrow S^k(T^*M)\otimes\Lambda^2(T^*M),
$$
in other words, the following sequence
$
0\to S^{k+2}(T^*M)\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_k^A\xrightarrow{\delta}\g_k^F\to 0
$
is exact. 
Therefore, the Hilbert function ${\rm H}^F(k)=\dim\g_k^F$ of the Maxwell equations is equal to
$
  {\rm H}^F(k)=2(k+1)(k+3).
$%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Symbols of the Einstein--Maxwell equations}%
Symbols of the Eins\-tein--Maxwell equations
$$
  \g_k^{EM}\subset S^k(T^*M)\otimes S^2(T^*M)\oplus S^k(T^*M)\otimes\Lambda^2(T^*M)
$$
are direct sums
$
  \g_k^{EM}=\g_k^E\oplus\g_k^F.
$
Therefore, the Hilbert function 
$$
  {\rm H}^{EM}(k)=\frac23(k+3)(k^2+9k+5)+2(k+1)(k+3)=\frac23(k+3)(k^2+12k+8).
$$%..................................................................................................................\subsubsection{Hilbert function for relativistic electromagnetic invariants}%
We get the Hilbert functions ${\rm H}_{\EM}$ of field of relativistic electromagnetic invariants:
\begin{align*}
 k=0,&\qquad{\rm H}_{\EM}(0)=2,\\
 k=1,&\qquad{\rm H}_{\EM}(1)=56-2-4\cdot 10=14,\\
 k\geq 2,&\qquad{\rm H}_{\EM}(k)=4k(k+3).
\end{align*}
The number of independent invariants of pure order $k$ for small orders are shown in the following table.
\medskip\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$k$ & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7\\
\hline
$\quad{\rm H}_{\EM}$ & 2 & 14 & 40 & 72 & 112 & 160 & 216 & 280 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsection{The Poincare function for the field of relativistic electromagnetic invariants}%
From the above results, we get that the Poincare function for field of relativistic electromagnetic invariants is the following
$$
  {\rm P}_{\EM}(t)=\sum_{k\geq 0}{\rm H}_{\EM}(k)\,t^k
=\frac{2(t^4-4t^3+2t^2+4t+1)}{(1-t)^3}.
$$%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%\begin{thebibliography}{30}
